Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Really in your face aromas, sweet and malty tones. Flavors are more mild and sweet, not as intense liquor influence.

Just about clear dark brown pour with a thin khaki head fizzy with no lacing .... Aroma of dark fruits/raisins, coconut, bourbon, oak, some roasted/chocolate malts and a bit boozy ..... Taste is of cinnamon, dark fruits/raisins, bourbon, vanilla, dry oaky, some roasted/chocolate malts and some light heat on the back end ..... abv hidden very well ...... finish is dry with a short bitter bite ... ends pretty abruptly .... a solid balanced brew excellent flavors and amazingly holds the abv back
Bottle from craft. Raisin, wood, bread, pepper, caramel and sugar. All blended excellently. The finish was mildly sweet and peppery. Very good.

From bottle at the recommendation of one of the employees at Total Wine & More. Dark brown pour with a medium tan head of largish bubbles. Big aroma of bourbon and dark fruits. Taste is raisins and plums and dark fruits, bourbon. I dont sense the cinnamon or chili peppers. This is very sweet. Extremely delicious but sweeter than I want frequently. On occasion, this will be just the beer. Pricey. But very very nice.

Bottle share, thanks GothGargoyle! Deep dark hazy brown. Aroma of raisin, vanilla, bourbon, and sweet cinnamon. Taste is outstanding dry spice sweetness. Palate is a clean, sharp dryness. Unbelievable mask of 13.7%.

Dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is raisins, chocolate, brown sugar, bourbon, dates, cinnamon. Medium-full bodied, sweet and fruity on the palate, lightly spicy finish. Taste is brown sugar, cinnamon, raisins, chocolate, well integrated spicy notes. Delicious.
Bottle. Pours deep amber with a beige head. Faint roasted malts, some chocolate and caramel malty sweetness, light spicy notes, coconut?, and some faint boozy notes. Pretty good.

A quickly fading beige head fades over the dull dark brown pour. Fruity and spicy, heady nose. Rich and supremely sweet offering reminiscent of the nutmeg and cinnamon raisin French Toast I had for breakfast, but add a melted chocolate and chili bar in there. Oatmealy texture, chewy and cakey. It does not burn the palate from the get go, but quickly warms you up and that alcohol pairs with the chilies. Minty, coconut and vanilla hints contribute more than a little credibility to the statement that this is one complex beast, but the heat is a bit annoying and the Judgment Days usual inviting fruitiness is lost in there. One thing is for sure, in spite of its sojourn in a bourbon barrel, it has not lost much body. Ironically, this is one beer that you would tend to want to roll over your tongue to explore its multi-faceted flavors, but the burn makes you swallow promptly and you end up drinking it faster than youd have thought. Guess they call that drinkability. In the end, there are too many ideas thrown into that bottle for it to create an ensemble you would want to visit frequently.

Pours thick dark raisin amber with a sandy colored head. Phenomenal aroma of dark fruit, brown sugar, and sweet perfumey booze. Flavor brings sweet brown sugar and the impression of rum and dark fruit from the sweet raisins. So smooth for the 13.7 ABV!

Bottle: Deep, deep brown; appears nearly black in the glass with a ruby glaze to it. Sizable, foamy tan head slowly settles to a chunky film & ring. Aroma has big notes of creamy milk chocolate, whiskey, woody vanilla, & a lovely, sweet cinnamon candy spice. Hints of dark fruit & roast as well. I can definitely see the "oatmeal cookie" vibe in the aroma. Lots of barrel presence on the palate. Big time whiskey soaked wooden staves, warming the throat & lightly tannic on the tongue. Raisin is more dominant with a huge, malty underbody. Dark cacao, roast, faint vanilla, star anise, & bourbon. Cinnamon is not as present, but can be found if you try hard enough. Some chili warmth in the aftertaste is noticeable & compounds with the heft & booziness of the beer to spark a huge warming sensation all the way down to your belly. Possibly a little over carbonated, a little prickly & tannic at times, but not a huge hinderance. Overall, a pretty nice beer with lots going on. Definitely feeling the warmth of this one.
Deep red with a spoiled raisin and plum body. Deep red fruits marry with a natural yeast flavor. Sweet and unique.

Bottle. Cherry brown. Aroma is chocolate covered bourbon soaked raisins. The taste brings out some cherry and cinnamon notes. The carb is a little too high for my taste but it doesn't detract from the flavor. Very complex and interesting. Great brew

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Dark ruby with a thin off white head. Aroma is raisin, bourbon barrel, vanilla and raisin. Taste adds raisin bread, cinnamon and a hint of pepper. Slightly thin and very sticky. Very very tasty.

Bottled. Pours hazy, mahogany with medium sized beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, wood, bourbon, spices and over ripe fruits. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry and with some chili notes and alcohol. Full bodied, syrup texture and flat carbonation. A very nice an complex Quad.

Bottle from a secret spot and pretty expensive considering the size but whatever. Definite plum and raisin aroma with a touch of pepper spice. Sticky sweet and lots of dark fruit flavors. Hot pepper burn on the back end of the palate. Not getting too much cinnamon. Vanilla and wood are there though from the barrel. A pretty good drink. Very complex very diverse and all working together pretty well.

16.9 oz. cc bottle that I was amazed to find at Whole Foods Plymouth. Poured turbid chestnut, looking deep brown through direct light, with 2-finger khaki head. Nose is prunes, raisins, brown sugar, heavy bourbon, oak, and bready malt. Tastes complex, with notes of oaky bourbon, raisins, cinnamon, brown sugar, berries, figs, and spirits. Finishes complex, with more fruity tartness.

375 c&c from Bine & Vine. Pours dark brown with a fizzy/creamy tan head. Aroma of cinnamon and dark fruits. Med body or so. Fizzy carbonation. Flavor is cinnamon, probably raisin, and plummy darkness. Its rather unusual, but Im liking it. Not particularly getting chili, and the bourbon is present but rather restrained. Whats most surprising is that the heat really doesnt hit until it goes down the gullet - burn in the esophagus perhaps, but not in the mouth. Pretty tasty, and - well its certainly tasty. My creative descriptability just ran dry.

Pours opaque black with a fizzy light tan head. 

Smells of cinnamon, dark fruits, bourbon and raisins. Delicious smelling beer.

Bourbon, raisins and cinnamon all mix well with the smoothness of a well brewed quad. Absolutely delicious. A little boozy on the back end, but thats expected with a 13.8% beer.

Wonderful carbonation followed by a heavy thickness that Im quite the fan of.

Yeah..this is a good one. Well worth the price. Great bourbon character, yet the quad side of it doesnt slack at all. Its a monster.

375ml bottle pours a murky, mahogany brown with some creamy, beige head. Nose has prunes, dried cherry, clove, candy sugar, fruit cake, raisin. Flavor is malty, fruit cake, the chile is throughout with some heat and raisin, prunes, dates, clove, a little chapstick. Sticky, spicy finish.

Thanks to errl for sharing this bottle. Dark brown pour with a tan head. The aroma has some heavy cinnamon and chili pepper notes that I am really digging. The flavor is a mix of heavy cinnamon, heat from the peppers and something that tastes just like oatmeal raisin cookies. This tastes like a mole beer that was dry hopped with oatmeal raisin cookies. Very tasty overall. Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Glad I got to try it.

12.7oz bottle. Opened to a very loud pop. Poured a dark brown color with an off white head. Woody, bourbon, vanilla, cinnamon, chilies, some roast, and some dark chocolates. Not overly cinnamon spice or overly chili hot (but both present. Overall alcohol content hidden.

500 bottle, Dark Brown pour. Big Cedar wood nose with Bourbon. Up front Bourbon and chocolate raisins, followed by cinnamon, with chile peppers in the background. Well blended and smooth. some burn in the finish. I like the analogy of a Oatmeal Raisin cookie.

Aroma: Raisins, Sweet Bread, Mild Sweet Bourbon

Appearance: Black Hue, Passes Almost No Light, No Head, No Lacing

Taste: Raisins, Sweet Bread, Bourbon, Mild Molasses

Mouthfeel: Average Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Sweet, Mildly Boozy
Bottle...Pour is black with a fading white head..Nose is amazing bourbon, raisin, spice, chocolate, rich alcohol, chilies..Taste is amazing bourbon, oak, spice, chewy pecans, rasins..

Bottle thanks to Duke.  Pours a deep brown with small tan head.  Aroma is big bourbon booze, big sweet malt, vanilla, cocoa, cinnamon raisin, hints of sour fruits.  Taste is vanilla bourbon with a cayenne aftertaste, dark chocolate and sweet cinnamon caramel as well.  Very complex nose.  Pretty full mouthfeel, warming spicy finish.

Cloudy dark brown-black. Minimal light tan head. Smells predominantly of bourbon and alcohol. Molasses. Cinnamon, spice. Bitter, some sweetness. Spiciness on the back. Incredibly long finish. Quite sweet all the way through. Very thick and oily, coats the palate. Alcohol is very upfront. Very interesting, quite good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Supermarket Liquors, Fort Collins. Pours dark brown with an attractive tan head and a fruit and molasses aroma. There is a sweet dark malt flavor with some brown sugar, treacle, cinnamon and bourbon. Slightly bitter finish. Complex and very tasty.
Tastes like cinnamon raison cookies but the raisons were soaked in bourbon. Absolutely delicious.

12.7 oz bottle. Dark brown with beige foam. Nose is raisin, bourbon, toffee and cinnamon with a chili sting. Medium body with fuzzy carb. Taste is bourbon, raisin, muted cinnamon and chili adding slight heat. Finishes slightly bitter with wood. Everything works together quite nicely without any ingredient overpowering; the alcohol as subtle as the spice.
375-ml bottle from wlvliquors. raisins in the nose, chiles in the mouth. if you ask me, should be categorized as a quintuple.

Bottle via craftshack shared at RBSDADG 2014. Pours a deep brown body with light lacing. Aroma is cinnamon cookies, oak, sweet molasses, rich barrel character and vanilla. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of cinnamon, spices, faint chili, oak barrel, chocolate, molasses and holiday cookies. Really interesting and a wonderful treat.

Bottle from craftshack opens with a pfftttt confirming this one has carbonation. pours plum, thin light khaki head. Nose has pitted fruit, cinnamon, bourbon, vanilla. Taste is more cinnamon based, bourbon and pitted fruits still present. Big burly body, has a silky way about it. Excellent.

The base might be a Belgian quad, but this is about as far from the style as you can get. Thick and boozy, the bourbon plays a pretty big role but doesnt give off too much heat. lots of raisin and sweetness. There is a hint of cinnamon and pepper, but much more subtitle than hunah or abraxas.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2014 Immediately greeted by bourbon on the nose. Followed by big roasted malts, toffee, spices (assuming from the chiles), cinnamon, some oak and vanilla coming from the barrels. In the light, it appears a dark black with a brownish magenta foam rim and subtle alcohol legs. Taste is Immediate chile spice and cinnamon followed by big toffee, oak, raisins, nougat, molasses, candy sweetness, slick malt syrup and some faint barrel wood. Finish is residual chile spiciness which works well with the heat of the bourbon/alcohol content. Another home-run from lost abbey. Really rich and well balanced. A dark fruit forward beer. A+ rating.

Not a true quad per se, but incredibly good. Barrel-aging done right -- infusing the beer with aging goodness without being too heavy. Nicely carbonated, and the added fruit notes are present and perfectly in balance. However, the 13.7% is overkill. Too much alcohol heat going on. Either age it for a long time, or be forewarned. This wouldve been perfect at 10-11% ABV.
(375ml bottle) clear deep brown, lasting fine tan bubbles. Nose of rum raisins, brown sugar, bourbon, cream, light alcohol. Taste of raisin, alcohol, toasted brown sugar, coconut, vanilla, delicious.
On tap at Taps in Petaluma. Pours a black color with beige head. Mild bourbon aroma and flavor. The combination of bourbon and spice jumps out as a coconut taste.

Bottle. Pours a dark chestnut brown, fluffy tan head with excellent retention, not much lacing though. Nose is cinnamon, boozy barrel-ness, milk chocolate, cinnamon, butterscotch and anchos. Mouth is medium bodied (kind of thins out though around mid-range), big bourbon notes up front, then chocolate covered raisins, vanilla, cinnamon, very mild heat from chiles and some from the ABV too. Intriguing and tasty, but the base beer gets more of a boost from the barrel aging than anything else (and definitely not worth the sticker price given the amount in the bottle). And I fucking hate math, so the satanic kid doing the problem on the blackboard annoys me.

Dark brown hazy pour with long lasting beige head. Nose is cinnamon, brown sugar, bourbon, vanilla, plums, dark fruits, toast. Flavor is bourbon, plums, dark fruits, cinnamon, clove, toast, caramel. Finish isnt too boozy, smooth yet warming, with a dry mouthfeel. Very complex and tasty brew!

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a nice 1+ finger tan head... Nice pop when opening the bottle. Huge cinnamon nose with bourbon barrels coming through along with pepper notes and vanilla. Full body with big cinnamon, candi sugar, dark fruits and vanilla notes. The cinnamon really lingers and has a cookie aftertaste. A big sweet beer with multiple layers. Dessert in a bottle. Very good.

Dark mahogany brown in color... Aroma is huge of cinnamon, raisins, vanilla, bourbon, candi sugar, chili peppers... Flavor is cinnamon initially, like Hunahpus, but raisins, dark fruit come through, peppers on finish... Heat on palate... Really nice 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12.7 oz. bottle poured to snifters, showing a murky, ruby highlighted, dark brown color, with a quickly diminishing head of tan foam, and a light display of lacing. The nose was expressive notes of barrel induced coconut, bourbon, raisin, and caramel sweetness, with a more subdued nature to the spice as cinnamon & light pepper, that seemed to dwell on the fringe almost as an afterthought, but understandably so, with everything else going on. The taste mimicked these notes well, adding moderate bitterness, decent enough effervescence to successfully project the flavor, and quite boozy, but warming alcohol. An extremely flavorful, complex concoction.
Bottle. Pours a murky brown with no head. The aroma is oak, booze, raisin, figs. Thin mouthfeel with strong raisin oatmeal and oak with boozy finish. Good.

Bottle @ Theis. Pours unclear hazel with no head. Aroma is vanilla, cinnamon, bounty, dark chocolate, figs and booze. Taste is heavy sweet and light+ bitter. Body is medium+, texture is heavy oily, carbonation is near flat. Finishes very sweet with bounty and cinnamon. Very low drinkability.

38cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2012, with raisins, cinnamon and chili peppers, thx to Brent and Dirk for sharing!, complex brew, alcoholic/fruity and slightly spicy/sweet, heavy, yet balanced, hazy, nearly no head, good brew, WOW!

Bottle @ The HUGE Tasting. Deep brown with a small head. The nose is rich chocolate cake. A bit of hot, spicy peppercorn. Strawberry syrup. The taste is or oatmeal raisin cookies. Chocolate vanilla brownies. A bit of toasted shredded coconut on the finish. Big, fat oily body. Another excellent track set entry.

Bottle. Pours opaque mahogany with a wispy tan ephemeral head that disappears as quickly as it forms, leaving just a touch of lacing. Aroma is light, with bourbon, dark fruits, coconut. Flavor is medium sweet, strong coconut, chili, dark sugars and fruits, cinnamon. Just a bit of astringency from the wood, but not much bitterness. A bit of heat on the finish belies the 13.7% ABV. Medium body, but quite creamy in the mouth. Effectively flat, which is a bit of a bummer, but hardly surprising.

3rd January 2014Mega Tasting at Bruces pad. Almost clear dark brown beer, small pale tan head. Palate is light and semi dry. Lovely dark chocolate and fruity bourbon. Big coconut with nicely integrated smooth cinnamon. Underneath are good dark fruits. Finishes light. Lovely!

I lived alone... my mind was blank ... Bottle shared at the BIG Friday tasting, massive thanks to our Ken for sharing the entire track set and also to Bruce for providing the accompanying music 03/01/14. 
Dark mahogony brown with thin light beige headwork.
Nose is dark toffee fudge, coconut shavings, sugars, boozey notes, dark fruit, dates, woody, fruit cake mix.
Taste comprises dark fruits, coconut cake, boozey underpin, toffeee, muscavado sugars.
Full bodied, fine carbonation, big boozey closure.
Decent enough quad, a little too much boozey heat but not totally overwhelming, glad to be sharing this one though!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle, generously shared by Kenny at the BIG Friday tasting. It pours near opaque brown with a small beige head. The nose is earth, wood, toasted coconut, dark chocolate, vanilla and light spice. The taste smooth, woody, earth, light chilli spice, treacle, chocolate, some astringency, dark, coconut and warming alcohol. Full body and soft carbonation. Smells rather nice, but a bit astringent and hot for my liking. Solid stuff nonetheless.

Bottle shared during the Track Set interval of the Brokeback Revisited tasting in London. Cheers Kenny! Good song pairing. Nose is very big on the coconut, nice dose of aniseed, toasty, citric rind, vanilla and heavy spices. Taste is overwhelming coconut. It is just so in your face which I enjoy. Some spice and dark, bitter chocolate come out to play. Nice kick of heat to finish with the spice. Coconut is the main man here. Great stuff

Bottle shared in London during the Track Set portion of the First 2014 Tasting. Paired correctly to the music. Thanks Ken. Pours unclear brown with a slight tan cream cap. Lovely nose, lots of chocolate sundae, coconut, banana. Medium to big sweet flavor with oily coconut, ripe bananas, faint chocolate, cake. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Oily finish, more coconut, mild cocoa, banana, faint toffee, golden raisins, sugary bread. Quite decadent but still very drinkable.

Svartbrun. Doftar tydligt mjuk pepparkaka. Alkoholer och ite estrig. Kanel och pepparkaka. Svagt värmande både från chili och alkohol, precis lagom. Låg kolsyra. Söt och svagt inslag av bourbon. Tänker snarast på en pumkin ale.
Bottle at Theis. Thick dark brown with no head. Cinnamon, vanilla, coconut, dark fruits, alcohol. Bounty bar bonanza. Medium/heavy sweet and a bit boozy. I like it, but in small amounts.

Bottle at Theis.
Hazy red-brown coloured with a small off-white head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of caramel, marzipan and coconuts with notes of bourbon and cinnamon.
Sweet and roasted flavour of coconuts, caramel and alcohol with notes of cinnamon.
Warming alcoholic finish.

Bottle at Theis LA-box tasting. Pours a hazy brown with no head. Smells of coco nut and spirits. Very very sweet with loads of Bounty Bar aromas. Hints of cinamon and chocolate. Very sweet - would work well with a baklava, kanelsnegl or citronmåne. Medium to full bodied. Soft carbonation. Long sweet finish. To much Bounty Bar extract.

Bottle at home. Cloudy deep red/brown - no head - no carbonation. Coconut, sweetness, roasted malts, light raisins, wooden notes, fruity estery notes, fresh coconut drying, bounty chocolate bar, high sweetness, light boozy.

Bottle at the tap room.
Aroma is a balanced blend of malt, yeast and bourbon. Moderate toffee, dark caramel and chocolate with light roast. Fruit esters of raisin and prune. Some alcohol and spice as it warms.
Pours a fairly murky brown with a slightly tan head that recedes fairly quickly. Light lacing and moderate legs.
Flavor similar but with more chili and spice. Nice toffee and dark caramel with some chocolate and light roast. Fairly sweet and slightly sticky. Moderate raisin notes with some prune and fig. Medium low chili flavor with medium light spice. Low bitterness to balance to sweetness. Some alcohol in finish; more as it warms. Moderately high bourbon throughout but not overpowering. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium low carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall a fairly enjoyable beer but less of a quad and more of a Belgian stout. The malt was fairly dark and it wasnt as fruity as I would expect for a quad. The mouthfeel also seemed bigger. Bourbon was fairly strong but worked really well.

Poured from the bottle at the tap room. Dark caramel color with minimal head. Big raisin and bourbon nose. Tastes like an oatmeal raisin cookie with bourbon glazing. Remarkably easy drinking for such a high abv.

Bottle @ The Lost Tasting Of Abbey Beers, Odense 2013. Pours dark brown with off-white head. Aroma is chocolate, cinnamon, cherries and raisins. Flavour is mainly cinnamon, with notes of raisins, chocolate, sherry. It has a bourbon and chilli finish to it. Too much cinnamon, which hides the rest of the beer.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty spicy cinnamon aroma with weak yeasty hints. Roasted malty spicy cinnamon and chocolate flavor with weak hints of chili. Has a roasted malty spicy chocolate and cinnamon finish.

Aromas are very dominated by cinnamon, chili, sugar, alcohol

Re-rated about one year later and what a difference! Very nice oaky cherry notes, roasted malts, burnt sugar, chocolate. Complex and very nice!

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2014 Pours dark brown to black with no head. Aroma of muscovado and loads of cinnamon, light pepper, tons of cocos. Taste is incredibly sweet with huge cocos and vanilla. Finish is rich sweet. Body is rich and creamy with no carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2015 The Lost tasting of Abbey beers, 2013. Unclear brown body with a small offwhite head. Aroma is cinnamon, spices, cookies, booze. Flavor is sweet, cinnamon, more cinnamon, chili notes, spices. The aroma is good, the flavor is wierd. 7,4,5,3,14

Dark brown body with a small offwhite head. Bourbon, cinnamon, chilli, green peppers, notes of fresh coconut, oak. A bit thickly on the back of the tongue. Dont know why I rated it so low 1st time I had it! This is rather delicious. 8,4,8,4,16

Bottle @ The Lost Tasting Of Abbey Beers, Odense 2013. Dark ruby brown with a small off-white head. The aroma is dominated by cinnamon, but its almost acceptable with so much else going on: Oatmeal cookies, indeed. raisin, toffee and a hint of alcohol. Sweet malty flavour with heavy cinnamon, some alcohol and a hint of chili heat. Well made beer suffering from cinnamon

Bottle @ The Lost Tasting Of Abbey Beers, Odense 2013. Pours dark ruby amber with a small bubbly head. Nose is cherries and cinnamon. Quite one dimensional but harmonic in a way. Raisins, cinnamon and cherries. Smooth and full bodied. Warming alcohol with a scent of chili warmth.

Pours dark dark brown but pools into black with zero head. The nose is as they intended. Oatmeal raisin cookies. Vanilla, raisins, cinnamon, nutmeg, dates, light chocolate.  The taste is high sweet and low bitter with a sweet aftertaste. The texture is soft and smooth with some nice alcohol warming and a small bite in the back of the throat from the chili.  The body is heavy with a long finish.

Pours a dark mahogany color with a tan head.  Aroma is cinnamon, chili, and light bourbon.  Taste is sweet with plenty of spice.  Smooth and slick.  Really fantastic.

Bottle courtesy of Vincent. Pours a deep black with little head. Nose of cinnamon, vanilla, bourbon. Taste like a snickerdoodle but I get the oatmeal cookie comparison.  I didnt get much of the heat or pepper flavor.  But this is really delicious.  Thanks for sharing Vin

Bottle with bill and tom, pours purple black with light head. Aromas and taste of oatmeal cookie, vanilla bean, booze, barrel, subdued chili, bourbon and hops. Medium body,  Lots of flavor. As it warmed the pepper and heat came out. Lots of cinnamon stick and ginger bread, heat creeps. Awesome.

Smells like a cinnamon chocolate stout. Seriously, cinnamon galore!

Kinda flat, but that's ok. This tastes like a cinnamon-sugar churro. Seriously. And I fucking love churros.

Bottle... This beer rocks!... Brown pour with a mahogany hue and a small, quickly dissipating, off-white head. The aroma is a lush blend of Amaretto, milk chocolate, fresh-sticky vanilla beans and a fantastic, but not overbearing, cinnamon component. Full-bodied and creamy with tickling carbonation. The flavor is a wonderful swirl of sweet chocolate, coconut and roasted pistachios with plenty of cinnamon and vanilla in the finish. Nothing not to love here!
Bottle.  Dark brown pour with a fleeting white head.  Cinnamon and vanilla nose.  Kinda watery with muted chilled, cinnamon, and vanilla lowlights.

Bottle pours with a light mahogany hued body that supports a thin tan head of foam. The aroma offers up cinnamon, molasses, ginger and chocolate with a solid ginger bread cookie sensation too. The taste is very Christmas like with cinnamon covered ginger bread cookie. It then gets into some coconut and bourbon booze notes into the finish. Nice stuff.
Bottle shared at the Santa Cruz boxset tasting. Aroma is basically apple cinnamon oatmeal. Flavor is massive cinnamon/goldschlager with a mild chili zestiness. Too heavy on the spice.
Dark brown pour, small head.  I get lots of spice, cinnamon, peppers, bourbon, toasted oak, a hint of licorice.  vanilla shows int he flavor with some spice cake and cookies.  Good!

375mL big thanks to dfroms! Label has a classroom chalkboard on the front with a long equation that answers to 666 Im assuming. Clear, deep brune pour. Weak head. Nose is cinnamon French toast straight up with some sharp balancing chili pepper. Taste is the same: egg yolk density, toasted bread crust, cinnamon, butter, maple. Really delicious dessert beer. Palate is silky, rich, dessert like. Pretty incredible experience.

Bottle courtesy of Dan the Man, thank you sir!  Oily black color, small beige head.  Aroma of toasted coconut, peppermint candy, licorice, Mars bars & Raisinettes.  Taste is smooth burnt licorice, spearmint.  Delicious.

Pour on tap at the Denver Rare Beer Tasting 2012, dark brownish purple pour with thin tan head, aroma brought notes of cinnamon, ginger, touch of raisin, sweet plum, fig, hints of roast, slight cocoa, hints of slight sour grainy notes, a bit odd.  Taste is a mix of sweet dark fruits with plum, fig, lots of rum soaked raisins, nice spice notes with cinnamon, ginger, some slight heat, finishing fairly sweet, slightly dry.  Interesting for sure.

Draft at Fobab 10. Pours a deep reddish brown. offwhite head. The nose shows a ton of cinnamon. Fresh ground. Earhty chilies come in as well. Chocolate, fig, raisins. On tasting, it is a big beer. boozy bourbon notes come through, along with a distinct vanilla hit. Not really sweet. Vanilla and cinnamon, with the cinnamon lending some astringency to balance everything. Really neat beer.

Sample FOBAB 12 - I regret to say I have never tried the base beer to this BA offering, but dried chiles in the description brought me to the table.  Aroma is spicy - cinnamon very forward - roasted malt, booze, some fruit.  Flavor is a bit more sweet than I anticipated after the aroma - the chiles are in there, but not at a prominent role, which is both good and bad.  Spice, chocolate, roasted malts and some bourbon/wood are evident.  Palate pretty smooth and lingers for a while.  Good offering!

Lost Abbey track beer tasting. 

Side by side with Judgment Day. 

The beer is a similar color to the base beer, with more head and longer retention. Thats what she said! The aroma brings cinnamon, perhaps nutmeg, oak, booze. The flavor is quite nice, and a noticeable improvement over the base beer. Well balanced and silky smooth on the palate. Lingering malt with a bouquet of spices. Tasty beer.

Lost Abbey Track beer tasting. Poured a cola color, not a lot of head here. No real head to this one. Aroma is notes of cinnamon and some touch of chili pepper. Flavor is plenty of cinnamon and some chili pepper heat. Not bad here.

Fobab #12
Pours a deep brown with a small head.

The aroma is earthy and has a good bit of dark chocolate, its boozy, spicy, and lightly sweet with some mild roastiness and a good bit of toffee. 

The flavor is sweet & bourbony. The spices and peppers I dont really find to be much of a central character of the beer but rather just sort of blended in well to the whole. The roastiness is higher than in most quads as is the bitterness. The fudgy chocolate is a good touch to a very big but well balanced beer.

Sampled at FoBAB 10 - 2012 (Chicago, IL). Pours a richer deep brownish hue, good haze and deep hues. A frothy offwhite head dies to a film. Aromas are gentle spice, oak and red fruit, dried raisins, gentle spice and caramel, toffee, biscuits. Some gentle heat. Initial is a bit vinous, dark fruit and plums, some raisin, bourbon, oak. Gentle carmelization, kiss of spice, bigger ABV but really works well for me. Middle is gentle sweetness, touches of spice, toffee, dark fruit, bit of heat, oak. Rich flavors envelope the palate, great flavors. Backend shows a bt of heat, toast and dryness. Gentle vinous dark fruit, spirit. Really nice Quad, gentle heat, rich flavors, nothing overdone. Great Quad with some healthy yet less stated barrel. Quality. Im amazed that the spirit gets muffled in this bad boy. I can see why others may not like it, its a bit sweet, big, and unapologetic about it. Some oak and spirit make it even more like an overbearing parent. But really, I quite enjoy it.

This one poured a medium to dark brown color with a beige head.  Aroma was lots of smores, cinnamon and bourbon.  Smelled more like smores than any beers ive ever head.  Flavor was much the same, very sweet, marshmellows, chocolate, dark fruits, bourbon, and light chile heat. I liked this one the best of the tracks I have had.
Fobab. Pours amber brown with a beige head. Whiskey sweetness, toffee malts, light woody notes and lighter spicy fruity yeasty notes. Pretty good. Barrel adds a good dimension.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2015 Bottle shared by thomashall. Pours a hazy deep brown with a tan head that dissipates to the edges quickly. Aroma has a good amount of sweet grains, dark fruits, cinnamon, chilies and a hint of raisin. Flavor is more cinnamon forward with sweet grains and raisin supporting as well as touches of peppers underlying.
Very much on the lines of a Hunah or Abraxas. A ncie chile and cinamon infused stout.

On tap: The aroma consists of cinnamon, raisins, chocolate, and vanilla. Its a brownish-orange with a small beige head. The flavor starts with cinnamon rolls and light raisin. The finish has chocolate, vanilla, and a touch of whiskey. Its medium-full bodied with mild carbonation.

Sample at Denver Rare Beer Tasting IV on 10/12/2012. The beer pours a dark reddish-brown color with a medium thin light beige head that dissipates to an outer ring. Short strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of oak, dark fruit and spices. Full, chewy body with flavors of raisins, molasses, cinnamon and caramel malt. The finish is oaky vanilla and malt. Good sipper all around.
Had at the 2012 Denver Rare Beer Tasting in Denver, Colorado. Great oatmeal/raisin scents, taste is a n ice roast, great beer.

Pour at the Denver Rare Beer Tasting IV. Appearance is dark brown with a small off-white head and decent lacing. Wood, dark fruits, light cinnamon, anise, black licorice, and potpourri in the aroma. Taste is spicy, cinnamon, light roast, and dark fruits, somewhat muddle flavors. Sticky body with no carbonation. Really weird beer.

Appearance: Pours an amber brown with a micro stripe of bubbles atop.

Aroma:  Cinnamon,brown sugar,ripe dark fruit. Caramel ,cocoa.

Taste: Anise, rum raisin, wood. Black pepper with lingering spice.

Mouthfeel: Prickly. Full bodied, harsh.

Overall: I thought this beer was too big and harsh when it was released, but see some potential for it by this same time next year. Great flavor profile, just too hot with too much bite.
...this beer is by far not what youd expect......your mind thinks judgement day on crack...your pallet says coconut ....its a very unique beer that shows Barrels Work magic!

Bottle at the brewery the day of the release. Pours with a near black hued body with a small tan head. Aromas are intense. Cinnamon churro, bready, bourbon, raisin, red wine, cherry, vinous. Doughy, rich and intense character. Light smoke. Flavors are of bourbon, brown sugar, cinnamon, chalky, tannin, chocolate, vinous, light heat. Hunaphu fans: eat your heart out! Rich date character, complex spices. Decadently enjoyable without being completely over the top. Full bodied, medium dry at this ABV with well hidden alcohol and a nicely balanced tannin. Very enjoyable.

Bottle consumed at the brewery a few days ago.  Pours dark brown almost black with a thin white head.  Aroma is lovely and very complex with various notes of cinnamon, coconut, gingerbread, butterscotch, vanilla toffee, raisins and other dark fruit, and boozy bourbon...but only a hint of the chilies.  Flavor is similarly complex with dry cinnamon and holiday spice, gingerbread, vanilla, sticky dark toffee, caramel, raisin, holiday fruitcake, and a significant amount of bourbon and whiskey.  The chilies are more noticeable in the mouth than the nose.  There is a nice level of sweetness here without being cloying at all.  Quite boozy in the finish, though.  This was my first taste of one of Lost Abbeys "Box Set" beers.  Judgment Day is one of my favorites from Lost Abbey, so I was eager to try this one in particular.  Yeah, their inspiration of oatmeal raisin cookies (dunked in bourbon, of course) sounds about right here.  It would make an excellent winter warmer or holiday beer...but I was drinking it on a very warm August day!  (6, 721)

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2012 Dark pour with razor thin off white head.  Nose was one of the best for my tastes with super over the top coconut, spices, and dark fruit.  Taste is also heavy on coconut but the base beer shines through nicely with dark fruit and raisins.  Judgement Day is one of my favorite LA regulars and I am a huge fan of strong coconut flavors in bourbon barrel aged beers.  This was a home run for me.

Bottle at lost abbey.  Very dark brown pour, reddish tinge.  Head was dark and short lived.  Very dark, chewy beer.  Dark fruit, raisin, molasses, cinnamon, vanilla, bourbon, cookie dough, Christmas spice, and bits of chili flavor here and there.  The thing that most comes to mind is cinnamon raisin oatmeal cookie, and a very good, dense, chewy cookie for sure.  Very good.

Poured from a bottle at Lost Abbey.  Pours dark brown with a some tan head.   Aroma is some cinnamon, but loads of coconut.  The taste was coconut gone crazy, cinnamon and spice cake.  The 13.7% was really well hidden.
